lexicon_requests.reason: Superscription puzzle - part of enigmatic 'al-mut labben' formula, unclear meaning
Superscription puzzle - 'for/of the son' in 'al-mut labben', LXX struggled with interpretation
Theological term for divine wonders - semantic range and connection to exodus tradition
Divine epithet 'Most High' - etymology and ANE comparative usage, shift from YHWH
First appearance in psalm - 'crushed/oppressed' - distinct from aniyim/evyon, need semantic nuance
Repeated fortress/haven metaphor - architectural and theological dimensions
Divine deeds/actions - concrete vs. abstract attributes, usage patterns
Blood-avenger participle - legal/redemptive terminology, go'el traditions
Distress cry/outcry - vocal dimension of suffering, theodicy implications
Pit imagery in reversal motif - cosmic/spatial theology, trap metaphor
Hapax with Selah - 'meditation/resounding music' - liturgical/theological marker at climax
Deliberate choice over adam/ish - mortality/frailty emphasis, wordplay in vv. 20-21
Fear/terror to be set on nations - LXX rendered as 'lawgiver', semantic range critical

commentary_requests.reason: Enigmatic superscription 'al-mut labben' - how do traditional commentators interpret this puzzling musical/liturgical notation?
Opening praise vow with 'all my heart' - classical understanding of wholehearted devotion and testimony dimension
Divine name progression from YHWH to Elyon - traditional interpretation of covenant vs. cosmic epithets
Theophanic presence causing enemy destruction - how commentators understand divine face/presence motif
Legal doublet mishpat/din and throne imagery - traditional juridical theology and courtroom metaphor
Name-blotting and eternal destruction - classical eschatology and memory theology
Broken syntax and emphatic finality - how commentators handle syntactic fragmentation and rhetorical effect
Structural pivot with eternal throne - traditional understanding of adversative shift and cosmic justice foundation
Universal judgment with righteousness/equity parallelism - classical interpretation of tzedek vs. mesharim
Application to the oppressed (dakh) - traditional social ethics and divine protection theology
Knowing God's name as basis for trust - classical covenant epistemology and name theology
Zion-dwelling and proclamation to nations - traditional Zion theology and witness mandate
Blood-avenger epithet and divine memory - classical go'el traditions and theodicy
Sudden petition shift and gates of death - how commentators explain transition from testimony to lament
Purpose of deliverance as testimony and daughter Zion - traditional understanding of salvation's testimonial goal
Reversal motif and poetic justice - classical interpretation of self-entrapment and measure-for-measure
Divine self-revelation and unique 'Higgaion Selah' - traditional understanding of this climactic liturgical marker
Jussive mood and Sheol destination - classical eschatology and forgetting-God theology
Temporal correction 'not forever' - how commentators handle this theodicy acknowledgment and justice gap
Urgent 'Arise!' imperative and enosh terminology - traditional understanding of divine inactivity complaint
Final petition with morah (fear) and enosh pedagogy - classical interpretation of nations learning creaturely limits

macro_questions: What is the significance of the incomplete acrostic structure shared between Psalms 9-10? Does the incompleteness serve theological purpose (justice not yet complete) or is it textual corruption?
How does the 'name theology' in this psalm (vv. 3, 6, 7, 11) relate to broader ANE concepts of name = essence/memory? What are the Ugaritic parallels for blotting out names?
What is the meaning of 'almuth labben' in the superscription (v. 1)? Does it indicate a melody, liturgical instruction, or thematic clue? How have scholars interpreted this phrase?
How do the perfect → imperfect → imperative verb sequences structure the psalm's theology of time? Is this a realized vs. future eschatology, or something more complex?
What is the relationship between mishpat (judgment/justice) in vv. 5, 8, 17 and the psalm's theodicy? How does 'righteous judgment' function when evil persists?

How does Zion theology (vv. 12, 15) function in this psalm? Is 'daughter Zion' personification, geographical location, or theological symbol? What is the relationship between God's universal throne (v. 8) and His reigning 'in Zion' (v. 12)?
What is the significance of the reversal motif in v. 16 (trapped in their own devices) for Israelite wisdom theology? Are there parallels in Proverbs or other wisdom literature?
How does the binary of 'nations/wicked' vs. 'afflicted/needy' function? Are these ethnic (Israel vs. nations) or moral (righteous vs. wicked) categories? Does the psalm conflate the two?
What is the function of 'Higgaion Selah' in v. 17? Is this a musical notation, meditation instruction, or theological marker? Why does it appear at the reversal motif?
How does the enosh (mortal humanity) wordplay in vv. 20-21 relate to Genesis 1-3 anthropology? Is this about human hubris forgetting creatureliness, paralleling the Babel narrative?
What is the relationship between 'knowing God's name' (v. 11) and nations 'knowing they are mortal' (v. 21)? Are these different types of knowledge (covenant vs. recognition of limits)?
micro_questions: What does the enigmatic superscription 'עַל־מוּת לַבֵּן' (almuth labben) mean, and why did even ancient translators (LXX) struggle to interpret it?
Why does the psalm use 'אֱנוֹשׁ' (enosh - mortal/frail human) in vv. 20-21 rather than 'אָדָם' (adam - humanity) or 'אִישׁ' (ish - man)? Is this deliberate wordplay emphasizing creaturely mortality?
What is the significance of 'הִגָּיוֹן סֶלָה' (Higgaion Selah) appearing uniquely in v. 17 at the reversal motif climax? Musical notation, meditation instruction, or theological marker?
How does the psalm's acrostic structure (if intentional but incomplete) relate to its theological content about incomplete justice?
Why the tension between past-tense claims of completed enemy destruction (vv. 6-7 'forever,' 'no more') and urgent present-tense petitions for God to judge enemies (vv. 20-21)?
What is the relationship between 'knowing God's name' (v. 11) and nations 'knowing they are enosh' (v. 21) - are these different epistemologies (covenant intimacy vs. forced recognition)?
How does 'bat-Tziyon' (daughter Zion, v. 15) function - as geographical location, personified city-as-woman, or theological symbol of covenant community?
Why do both legal terms 'מִשְׁפָּט' (mishpat) and 'דִּין' (din) appear together in v. 5? Are these synonyms for emphasis or distinct aspects of justice?
What does the reversal motif in v. 16 (nations trapped in own devices) suggest about divine justice - immanent moral consequences or direct divine intervention?
How does Zion theology (v. 12 'dwelling in Zion') relate to universal judgment claims (v. 9 'judges world') - is Zion cosmic center or particular sanctuary?
What is the significance of the LXX translating 'מוֹרָה' (morah - fear/terror) as 'νομοθέτης' (lawgiver) in v. 21? Does this reflect different understanding of divine pedagogy?
Why does v. 19's 'not forever shall needy be forgotten' seem to acknowledge current divine inaction/forgetfulness, contradicting vv. 8-9's eternal throne of justice?
How do the 'gates' metaphors function spatially and theologically - are sha'arei mavet (gates of death) and sha'arei bat-Tziyon (gates of daughter Zion) literal, metaphorical, or cosmological?
What is the function of the causative 'כִּי' clauses throughout (vv. 5, 11, 13, 19) - do they provide genuine reasons or rhetorical justifications for petition?
Why does the psalm end on petition + Selah rather than resolution or praise - is this liturgical strategy or theological statement about ongoing theodicy struggle?
